chapter.title: You will be silent, unable to speak

para.emphasis: The angel answered him, “I am Gabriel, who stands in the presence of God, and I was sent to speak to you and to bring you this good news. And now, because you did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their time, you will be silent, unable to speak, until the day these things take place.”

chapter.para: John the Baptist was to be the last prophet according to the Old Testament pattern. His calling was to prepare peoples' hearts for Jesus to come.

John was coming to a people who knew the Bible better than any of their forefathers. They had large parts of their Bible memorized. They had analyzed tiny details of the text's grammar for its minute flavors of meaning.
But they didn't know God. They had replaced relationship with human knowledge.

Zechariah was priest to God in the middle of this culture. Unlike the bulk of the culture, he still believed--in the abstract--that God could still work miracles. And he was praying for a miracle: a son. Even though he and his wife were too old to have children.
Zechariah's name means memory of the Lord, a fitting name for one of the few who was keeping alive the memory of a God who is alive.

sect1.title: Zechariah's obedience
sect1.para: Zechariah had entered the temple to burn incense. Revelation 5:8 and 8:3-4 identify incense as a symbol of the prayers of God's people.
Zechariah had entered instead of another priest because the Lord had revealed for him to be the one to serve through casting lots.
And in the Old Testament time, the Lord's presnce was in the temple in a special way and there was a special blessing when someone prayed to God in the temple.
So Zechariah was praying in the Temple, in God's presence. He was praying at a time God had revealed--when God spoke through casting lots that he wanted Zechariah to come near and pray.

And Zechariah was about to find out, in the most dramatic way possible, that he had been praying in God's will. Because God had sent an angel to meet Zechariah in that place and to deliver the message of God's promise of an answer.

sect1.title: This was a (humanly) impossible task
sect1.para: However, before such a child could
According to human ability, this was impossible.
Zechariah and Elizabeth were physically unable to bear children.

And they lived near the end of a corrupt priesthood that elevated itself above the people. The Pharasees elevated themselves as the true Bible teachers so much that they even built a second ramp for themselves to walk up to the temple. Their ramp separated them from the common people and was physically elevated above the one the regular people had to walk on to get up to the temple. The remains of this ramp are in Jerusalem to this day.

To raise a child as a priest in this environment who would truly turn the people to God, and not to a superstar preacher or musician (what the Pharasees were) was even more humanly impossible than for Zechariah and Elizabeth to have a child to begin with.
But what is impossible with men is possible with God.
John the Baptist was born and did carry out this whole task that the Lord gave him to do, though it cost him his very life.
What man couldn't do due to human limitations was very possible with God.

sect1.title: The answer
sect1.para: The answer that God had promised was far beyond what Zechariah had asked.
Zechariah had just aske for a child. And God had provided much more than any child. God promised a son who would carry the inheritance forward.

Naturally, the Lord was concerned with the spiritual.
